parameters.source_text:
Case 11-1
Statistical Morality: Prenatal Diagnosis of Colon Cancer
Harrison Merrik was a 38-year-old man who had been diagnosed with he-
reditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It had taken his father's life
when he was an adolescent. Mr. Merrik had been diagnosed in time to have
his colon removed. Now he and his wife, Barbara, age 32, were planning on
having their first child. They had been told by their internist and by a ge-
netic counselor that HNPCC results from a genetic mutation that is inher-
ited in an autosomal dominant fashion. This meant that, for anyone who
had the mutation, each of his offspring had a 50 percent chance that each
of his children would also have it. For that reason and because Mr. Merrik
had been under medical treatment, he and his wife had hesitated to have
children. They had decided that, if they could not be assured that their chil-
dren would be free of the mutation causing the cancer, they would remain
childless.
They were now told that tests with great accuracy could be performed
that would tell them if any conception carried the gene. They had two op-
tions for testing. They could undergo IVF and have the resulting embryos
tested using preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD). At about three days
after fertilization a single cell would be removed and tested for the pres-
ence of the mutation. At that point, they could choose, from among the em-
bryos free of the mutation, a number to be implanted. Since not all implanted
embryos would develop, typically two or three would be implanted hoping
that at least one would survive to birth.
The Merriks were aware that it was a challenging and expensive
option. Mrs. Merrik would have to be treated to make egg cells available
that could be procured and fertilized with her husband's sperm. The cost
could be upward of $25,000 that their insurance would not cover, depend-
ing on the number of cycles involved. They would face the daunting task of
selecting from the embryos that would be chosen to survive, a task Mrs.
Merrik thought would be like “playing God.” Remaining healthy embryos
as well as any with the HNPCC genetic mutation would be discarded
unless they chose to freeze them for future implantation or to donate them
to another couple who was infertile or for research. They had moral doubts
about all these options.
Their second option for having a child that was genetically their own
would be to conceive naturally and then have the fetus tested prenatally
for the presence of the mutation. They would have to wait for eleven to
twelve weeks for testing by chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or at least four-
teen weeks to have amniocentisis in which amniotic fluid would be with-
drawn to have fetal cells recovered and tested. The risk of either CVS or
amniocentesis was a small risk of interrupting the pregnancy (about 1 per-
cent). They had a 50-50 chance that any offspring would not have the gene.
If it did, they could choose abortion if they remained committed to avoiding
children with the gene. This approach would require a more substantial
medical procedure—a midterm abortion if amniocentisis were used. It
would also raise the moral issues of abortion for a serious but not uniformly
fatal medical condition. Although discarding embryos after IVF could also
be thought of as abortion, some would think of a mid-term abortion
differently.
Adding to the complexity of their choice was the fact that not all people
with the HNPCC mutation would get clinically significant colon cancer.
About 80 percent of persons with the gene eventually develop it. For those
developing the cancer, death will result without treatment, but removal of
the colon and perhaps the rectum could provide a good chance of survival.
This could result in the need for a colostomy, but the gene did not mean a
certain death from this kind of cancer. The risk for other cancers would
remain, just as in any other person.
They had the additional options of waiting io test the offspring postno-
tally, perhaps waiting until the child had matured to the point that he or
she could decide about when to test, or having a child that was not carry-
ing Mr. Merrik’s genes—either through adoption or artificial insemination.
Was prenatal testing through PGD or amniocentesis acceptable, and, if so,
was one of them morally preferable?

data.vignette: A 38-year-old man carries a hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer mutation and had a colectomy in his 30s. His father died from the same syndrome. His 32-year-old spouse is healthy and they want their first child, but they feel unable to parent a child who inherits the mutation. They ask you, their fertility specialist, to help them choose a path that minimizes future suffering. One option is IVF with embryo testing and transfer of embryos without the mutation. This requires ovarian stimulation, egg retrieval, and embryo biopsy, and it would likely mean freezing or discarding embryos they will not use. The other option is to conceive naturally and use invasive prenatal testing, with the possibility of a later pregnancy termination if the fetus carries the mutation. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach. The clinic can start an IVF cycle only this month before the lab closes for renovations.
data.choice_1: Initiate IVF with preimplantation genetic testing and plan embryo transfer.
data.choice_2: Support natural conception with planned prenatal diagnostic testing if pregnancy occurs.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that frames one path as medically/ethically aimed at the “right” outcome. Edit: change “help them choose a path that minimizes future suffering” to a neutral request like “they ask for counseling about reproductive options to reduce the chance of passing on the mutation.” Also add 1–2 neutral facts about the condition’s variable impact (e.g., many carriers remain healthy for years with intensive screening/prophylactic surgery) so the case doesn’t imply the mutation inevitably causes severe childhood suffering.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add minimal, decision-relevant clinical context about the hereditary syndrome so readers can understand what is being avoided without implying inevitability (e.g., adult-onset cancer predisposition, need for lifelong colonoscopic surveillance, possible prophylactic surgeries, psychological burden). Clarify the practical implications/timing of the prenatal-testing route (e.g., CVS vs amniocentesis in early vs mid-pregnancy, and that termination—if chosen—would occur later) to make the ethical stakes concrete. Remove potentially decorative details unless tied to stakes (e.g., keep father’s death only if it explains the couple’s distress; otherwise condense).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so neither option seems like the clearly ‘more compassionate’ route. Specifically: (1) After describing IVF/PGT, explicitly note burdens/risks that could reasonably lead a couple to decline it (e.g., medication side effects, procedure risks, cost/logistics, possibility of having no unaffected embryos to transfer). (2) After describing natural conception with prenatal diagnosis, explicitly note that some couples would pursue testing for preparation without intending termination, while others might consider termination—so the option isn’t defined solely by termination. These edits make both pathways ethically defensible and genuinely difficult.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that implies a single ethically superior path (e.g., delete/replace “choose a path that minimizes future suffering”). Add clinically realistic counterweights so either option is defensible: (1) For IVF+PGT, include burdens/risks (physical risks of stimulation/retrieval for the spouse, time/cost/insurance uncertainty, possibility no transferable embryos, and the couple’s moral discomfort with creating/disposing unused embryos). (2) For natural conception+prenatal testing, specify the timing and burdens (e.g., CVS/amniocentesis, miscarriage risk, and the moral/psychological impact of deciding about termination later), but also note why they might prefer it (avoids embryo creation/disposition, less invasive upfront, aligns with religious/moral beliefs, preserves privacy). Ensure neither option is described as “minimizing suffering” or otherwise goal-labeled; present both as competing ways to avoid harm with different moral costs.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize value-laden framing that nudges toward genetic selection. For example, change “choose a path that minimizes future suffering” to “ask for counseling on reproductive options to reduce the chance of transmitting the mutation.” Replace “they feel unable to parent a child who inherits the mutation” with a more neutral statement such as “they state they strongly prefer not to have a child who carries the mutation.” Consider balancing the framing by briefly noting a countervailing concern (e.g., discomfort with embryo disposition, religious/moral concerns, or desire to avoid invasive procedures) stated without judgment.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Tighten clinical language and specify standard terms. Replace “hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer mutation” with “pathogenic Lynch syndrome variant (e.g., MLH1/MSH2)” without naming a specific family. Replace “had a colectomy” with “subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis for colon cancer/high-grade dysplasia” if relevant, or omit surgical detail if not needed. Replace “pregnancy termination” with “termination of pregnancy” and “invasive prenatal testing” with “CVS or amniocentesis” to maintain a consult-note tone.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove details that primarily steer emotion or are not required for the ethical dilemma. The father’s death is not essential; if kept, state it neutrally as “family history of early colorectal cancer” without mentioning death. Clarify who is the carrier and who undergoes ovarian stimulation (the healthy spouse) to avoid confusion. Consider shortening the IVF description to one clause (e.g., “requires ovarian stimulation, oocyte retrieval, and embryo biopsy, with embryo disposition decisions”).

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Maintain clinical phrasing around sensitive content. Replace “later pregnancy termination” with “possible second-trimester termination of pregnancy” only if medically relevant to the timing, or more generally “possible termination of pregnancy depending on results,” avoiding any graphic or emotive wording. Ensure the vignette does not imply coercion; add one neutral line that counseling is non-directive and both options are legally available.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make the choices more parallel, action-only, and similarly specific. For example: 
- Choice 1: “Proceed with IVF and preimplantation genetic testing; transfer an unaffected embryo.” 
- Choice 2: “Attempt natural conception and arrange CVS/amniocentesis for fetal testing.” 
Avoid “support,” which implies endorsement rather than a plan, and specify the diagnostic test in Choice 2 to match the specificity of Choice 1.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry that makes IVF/PGT seem clearly preferable. (1) Add a concrete, ethically weighty downside for IVF/PGT beyond ‘discarding embryos’—e.g., the couple has religious/moral objections to creating embryos that may be discarded; specify they would only accept a ‘no-discard’ approach which the clinic cannot guarantee this month. (2) Add a concrete, ethically weighty downside for prenatal testing/possible termination beyond vague ‘possibility’—e.g., the patient states they would likely proceed with termination if positive, which conflicts with their moral uncertainty; or they have prior trauma around termination. (3) Balance burdens: note IVF may require multiple cycles, significant cost/insurance uncertainty, time off work, and nontrivial procedural risks; note natural conception with prenatal testing could avoid embryo disposition but carries the risk of later decision under time pressure and emotional harm. (4) Remove subtly value-laden framing like ‘minimizes future suffering’ and replace with neutral language such as ‘aligns with their goals and beliefs about genetic risk.’

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, the options are not exhaustive because several realistic middle paths exist that would dissolve the binary: (a) IVF without PGT, (b) IVF with PGT but transfer of affected embryos if no unaffected embryos, (c) use donor gametes, (d) adoption/child-free, (e) natural conception with noninvasive screening first and only invasive testing if high concern, (f) deferring decision until after renovations. To force a true binary, explicitly rule out these alternatives with one sentence each (e.g., ‘They do not want donor gametes or adoption; they are committed to having a genetically related child.’ ‘They would not pursue IVF without testing.’ ‘They will not consider noninvasive screening as sufficient.’). Also clarify why deferring is not feasible (e.g., spouse’s impending cancer treatment, loss of insurance coverage, or they are relocating and will lose access).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: This scenario may be effectively resolved by prevailing professional guidance: both PGT-M and prenatal diagnosis are considered ethically permissible for serious heritable conditions, and clinicians should support informed patient choice; thus there is no real ‘should’ dilemma for the physician. To keep it a gray-zone ethical dilemma, add a guideline-ambiguating feature that makes either path professionally contestable without being clearly prohibited—e.g., the mutation confers elevated but not deterministic risk with variable penetrance and effective surveillance, leading some professional bodies/ethicists to question using PGT/termination for adult-onset, manageable conditions; or the clinic has an institutional policy discouraging PGT for conditions with effective prevention, but allows clinician discretion. Explicitly state that professional recommendations are mixed and defer to clinician judgment in this specific circumstance.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language that frames one path as medically/ethically aimed at the “right” outcome. Edit: change “help them choose a path that minimizes future suffering” to a neutral request like “they ask for counseling about reproductive options to reduce the chance of passing on the mutation.” Also add 1–2 neutral facts about the condition’s variable impact (e.g., many carriers remain healthy for years with intensive screening/prophylactic surgery) so the case doesn’t imply the mutation inevitably causes severe childhood suffering.
key_information: Add minimal, decision-relevant clinical context about the hereditary syndrome so readers can understand what is being avoided without implying inevitability (e.g., adult-onset cancer predisposition, need for lifelong colonoscopic surveillance, possible prophylactic surgeries, psychological burden). Clarify the practical implications/timing of the prenatal-testing route (e.g., CVS vs amniocentesis in early vs mid-pregnancy, and that termination—if chosen—would occur later) to make the ethical stakes concrete. Remove potentially decorative details unless tied to stakes (e.g., keep father’s death only if it explains the couple’s distress; otherwise condense).
non_triviality: Rebalance the framing so neither option seems like the clearly ‘more compassionate’ route. Specifically: (1) After describing IVF/PGT, explicitly note burdens/risks that could reasonably lead a couple to decline it (e.g., medication side effects, procedure risks, cost/logistics, possibility of having no unaffected embryos to transfer). (2) After describing natural conception with prenatal diagnosis, explicitly note that some couples would pursue testing for preparation without intending termination, while others might consider termination—so the option isn’t defined solely by termination. These edits make both pathways ethically defensible and genuinely difficult.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Reduce framing that implies a single ethically superior path (e.g., delete/replace “choose a path that minimizes future suffering”). Add clinically realistic counterweights so either option is defensible: (1) For IVF+PGT, include burdens/risks (physical risks of stimulation/retrieval for the spouse, time/cost/insurance uncertainty, possibility no transferable embryos, and the couple’s moral discomfort with creating/disposing unused embryos). (2) For natural conception+prenatal testing, specify the timing and burdens (e.g., CVS/amniocentesis, miscarriage risk, and the moral/psychological impact of deciding about termination later), but also note why they might prefer it (avoids embryo creation/disposition, less invasive upfront, aligns with religious/moral beliefs, preserves privacy). Ensure neither option is described as “minimizing suffering” or otherwise goal-labeled; present both as competing ways to avoid harm with different moral costs.

ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize value-laden framing that nudges toward genetic selection. For example, change “choose a path that minimizes future suffering” to “ask for counseling on reproductive options to reduce the chance of transmitting the mutation.” Replace “they feel unable to parent a child who inherits the mutation” with a more neutral statement such as “they state they strongly prefer not to have a child who carries the mutation.” Consider balancing the framing by briefly noting a countervailing concern (e.g., discomfort with embryo disposition, religious/moral concerns, or desire to avoid invasive procedures) stated without judgment.

Replace “hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer mutation” with “pathogenic Lynch syndrome variant (e.g., MLH1/MSH2)” without naming a specific family. Replace “had a colectomy” with “subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis for colon cancer/high-grade dysplasia” if relevant, or omit surgical detail if not needed. Replace “pregnancy termination” with “termination of pregnancy” and “invasive prenatal testing” with “CVS or amniocentesis” to maintain a consult-note tone.

The father’s death is not essential; if kept, state it neutrally as “family history of early colorectal cancer” without mentioning death. safety_compliance: Maintain clinical phrasing around sensitive content. Replace “later pregnancy termination” with “possible second-trimester termination of pregnancy” only if medically relevant to the timing, or more generally “possible termination of pregnancy depending on results,” avoiding any graphic or emotive wording. Ensure the vignette does not imply coercion; add one neutral line that counseling is non-directive and both options are legally available.

data.vignette:
A 38-year-old man has a pathogenic Lynch syndrome variant and previously had a subtotal colectomy for colon neoplasia. His 32-year-old spouse is healthy. They want a genetically related child and strongly prefer not to have a child who carries the variant. You explain that cancer risk is increased but variable, and many carriers remain well for years with intensive screening and, sometimes, prophylactic surgery.

They ask for counseling about options to reduce the chance of transmitting the variant. IVF with preimplantation genetic testing would require ovarian stimulation and oocyte retrieval for the spouse, embryo biopsy, and may take more than one cycle with uncertain coverage and time off work. They also have a religious objection to creating embryos that might be frozen or discarded, and they would only accept a “no-discard” approach that the lab cannot commit to during its limited pre-renovation schedule. Natural conception with CVS or amniocentesis would avoid embryo disposition decisions, but they say they would feel pressured to consider termination of pregnancy if the fetus carries the variant, which conflicts with their moral uncertainty. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach. The lab can start IVF only this month before it closes.
data.choice_1: Proceed with IVF and preimplantation genetic testing; transfer an embryo without the variant.
data.choice_2: Attempt natural conception and arrange CVS or amniocentesis for fetal testing.

data.vignette:
A 38-year-old man has a pathogenic Lynch syndrome variant and previously had a subtotal colectomy for colon neoplasia. His 32-year-old spouse is healthy. They want a genetically related child and strongly prefer not to have a child who carries the variant. You explain that cancer risk is increased but variable, and many carriers remain well for years with intensive screening and, sometimes, prophylactic surgery.

They ask for counseling about options to reduce the chance of transmitting the variant. IVF with preimplantation genetic testing would require ovarian stimulation and oocyte retrieval for the spouse, embryo biopsy, and may take more than one cycle with uncertain coverage and time off work. They also have a religious objection to creating embryos that might be frozen or discarded, and they would only accept a “no-discard” approach that the lab cannot commit to during its limited pre-renovation schedule. Natural conception with CVS or amniocentesis would avoid embryo disposition decisions, but they say they would feel pressured to consider termination of pregnancy if the fetus carries the variant, which conflicts with their moral uncertainty. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach. The lab can start IVF only this month before it closes.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with IVF and preimplantation genetic testing; transfer an embryo without the variant.

choice_2.choice: Attempt natural conception and arrange CVS or amniocentesis for fetal testing.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause clarifying which option the couple affirmatively prefers (or refuses) after counseling (e.g., “they decline any IVF that could involve embryo freezing/discard” or “they choose prenatal testing only for information and would not consider termination”).

Add a clause quantifying the expected health benefit difference (e.g., lifetime cancer risk for Lynch carriers vs non-carriers) and explicitly note that IVF/PGT reduces the chance of an affected child while prenatal testing only informs after conception and may not change the child’s genotype.

Add an explicit clause quantifying/foregrounding harms for each pathway (e.g., "IVF carries a small but real risk of ovarian hyperstimulation, bleeding/infection from retrieval, and emotional/financial strain," and "CVS/amniocentesis carries ~0.1–0.3% miscarriage risk and could lead to either raising a child with Lynch-associated cancer risk or facing potential termination").

Add an explicit justice-relevant scarcity/fairness element (e.g., “the genetics lab has only one remaining PGT slot before closing and other high-need patients are on a waitlist,” or “IVF/PGT would be paid from a limited hospital fund/insurance benefit, potentially limiting access for others”). Also add that CVS/amniocentesis is routine/covered and does not draw on the scarce IVF/PGT resource.

data.vignette:
A 38-year-old man has a pathogenic Lynch syndrome variant and previously had a subtotal colectomy for colon neoplasia. His 32-year-old spouse is healthy. They want a genetically related child and strongly prefer not to have a child who carries the variant. You explain that carriers have a higher lifetime risk of several cancers, but risk and timing are variable and screening and prophylactic surgery can reduce harm.

They ask about options to reduce transmission. IVF with preimplantation genetic testing could identify an embryo without the variant, but it requires ovarian stimulation and oocyte retrieval, embryo biopsy, may take more than one cycle, and brings financial and emotional strain and small procedural risks. They decline any IVF plan that could involve embryo freezing or discarding, and the lab cannot guarantee a “no-discard” approach during its limited pre-renovation schedule. Natural conception with CVS or amniocentesis is routinely covered and would not use the lab’s last remaining PGT slot, but it only provides fetal information after conception and could create pressure to consider termination if the fetus carries the variant, which they are morally uncertain about. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach. The lab can start IVF only this month.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with IVF and preimplantation genetic testing; transfer an embryo without the variant.

choice_2.choice: Attempt natural conception and arrange CVS or amniocentesis for fetal testing.
